intro: Rubus sneydii, commonly known as the Sneyd's blackberry, is a species of bramble native to the western United States. It is characterized by its thorny stems and compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, aggregate fruits that are typically dark purple to black in color. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in forest understories. Botanically, it is part of the Rubus genus, which includes many other species of brambles and blackberries.
